  "body": "## Overview\n\n**Priority:** Major  \n**Source:** Multi-model analysis #309, #311, #313, #314, #319, #320, #322  \n**Related Finding:** M-1 from `docs/workflow/multi-model-review/merged-findings.md`\n\nWhile the project has comprehensive tests (370 tests with TUnit), there is no automated coverage collection, reporting, or enforcement. This prevents tracking coverage over time and detecting regressions.\n\n## Current State\n\n- `pr-validation.yml` runs tests but doesn't collect coverage\n- No Coverlet or similar coverage tool configured\n- No coverage threshold enforcement\n- No coverage badge in README\n\n## Recommendations\n\n### 1. Add Coverage Collection\n\n```yaml\n# In .github/workflows/pr-validation.yml\n- name: Test with coverage\n  run: dotnet test --collect:\"XPlat Code Coverage\" --results-directory coverage\n\n- name: Upload coverage to Codecov\n  uses: codecov/codecov-action@v4\n  with:\n    files: coverage/**/coverage.cobertura.xml\n    fail_ci_if_error: true\n```\n\n### 2. Configure Coverage Package\n\n```xml\n<!-- In test project or Directory.Build.props -->\n<ItemGroup>\n  <PackageReference Include=\"coverlet.collector\" Version=\"6.*\">\n    <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>\n    <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>\n  </PackageReference>\n</ItemGroup>\n\n<PropertyGroup>\n  <CoverletOutput>coverage/</CoverletOutput>\n  <Threshold>80</Threshold>\n  <ThresholdType>line,branch</ThresholdType>\n</PropertyGroup>\n```\n\n### 3. Add Coverage Badge to README\n\n```markdown\n[![codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/oocx/tfplan2md/branch/main/graph/badge.svg)](https://codecov.io/gh/oocx/tfplan2md)\n```\n\n## Success Criteria\n\n- [ ] Coverage collected on every PR\n- [ ] Coverage reports uploaded to Codecov (or similar)\n- [ ] Coverage badge in README\n- [ ] Minimum threshold enforced (start at 80%, target 90%+)\n- [ ] Historical coverage tracking enabled\n- [ ] PR fails if coverage drops below threshold\n\n## Implementation Notes\n\n- Set initial threshold at 80-85% to avoid blocking existing PRs\n- Gradually increase to 90%+ over time\n- Exclude generated files and test infrastructure from coverage\n",

Based on the GitHub issue, this is a request to add **automated code coverage reporting and enforcement** to the CI pipeline. The issue describes the current state and provides implementation examples, but as noted, the actual tool selection should be made by the architect.

Let me clarify a few key aspects with you:

**Understanding the Feature Request:**

The issue describes adding code coverage collection, reporting, and enforcement to catch test coverage regressions. The examples mention Codecov as a reporting platform, but you've noted that the architect should make the final tooling decisions.

**My Question:**

From a **user perspective** (developers working on the project), what would constitute "success" for this feature? Specifically:

1. Should coverage metrics be visible **within the PR interface** itself (e.g., as PR comments or checks), or is a link to an external dashboard sufficient?

**Next**
- **Option 1:** Answer the question above so I can better understand the desired user experience
- **Option 2:** Let me know if you'd like me to proceed with documenting the requirements as stated in the issue

**Recommendation:** Option 1, because understanding the visibility requirements will help define clearer success criteria.

  "body": "## Overview\n\n**Priority:** Major  \n**Source:** Multi-model analysis #309, #311, #313, #314, #319, #320, #322  \n**Related Finding:** M-1 from `docs/workflow/multi-model-review/merged-findings.md`\n\nWhile the project has comprehensive tests (370 tests with TUnit), there is no automated coverage collection, reporting, or enforcement. This prevents tracking coverage over time and detecting regressions.\n\n## Current State\n\n- `pr-validation.yml` runs tests but doesn't collect coverage\n- No Coverlet or similar coverage tool configured\n- No coverage threshold enforcement\n- No coverage badge in README\n\n## Recommendations\n\n### 1. Add Coverage Collection\n\n```yaml\n# In .github/workflows/pr-validation.yml\n- name: Test with coverage\n  run: dotnet test --collect:\"XPlat Code Coverage\" --results-directory coverage\n\n- name: Upload coverage to Codecov\n  uses: codecov/codecov-action@v4\n  with:\n    files: coverage/**/coverage.cobertura.xml\n    fail_ci_if_error: true\n```\n\n### 2. Configure Coverage Package\n\n```xml\n<!-- In test project or Directory.Build.props -->\n<ItemGroup>\n  <PackageReference Include=\"coverlet.collector\" Version=\"6.*\">\n    <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>\n    <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>\n  </PackageReference>\n</ItemGroup>\n\n<PropertyGroup>\n  <CoverletOutput>coverage/</CoverletOutput>\n  <Threshold>80</Threshold>\n  <ThresholdType>line,branch</ThresholdType>\n</PropertyGroup>\n```\n\n### 3. Add Coverage Badge to README\n\n```markdown\n[![codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/oocx/tfplan2md/branch/main/graph/badge.svg)](https://codecov.io/gh/oocx/tfplan2md)\n```\n\n## Success Criteria\n\n- [ ] Coverage collected on every PR\n- [ ] Coverage reports uploaded to Codecov (or similar)\n- [ ] Coverage badge in README\n- [ ] Minimum threshold enforced (start at 80%, target 90%+)\n- [ ] Historical coverage tracking enabled\n- [ ] PR fails if coverage drops below threshold\n\n## Implementation Notes\n\n- Set initial threshold at 80-85% to avoid blocking existing PRs\n- Gradually increase to 90%+ over time\n- Exclude generated files and test infrastructure from coverage\n",

response.value:
Great! The user has clarified that:
1. They prefer to see everything in the PR interface if possible
2. But they're open to linked reports if they provide a better experience
3. Coverage thresholds should be enforced as a PR check (pass/fail)

This helps me understand the user experience requirements. Now I should ask the next question to clarify other aspects. Let me think about what else I need to know:

- What should happen when coverage drops? (fail the PR? warning?)
- What coverage metrics matter? (line coverage, branch coverage, etc.)
- Should there be different thresholds for different parts of the codebase?
- What about baseline - should we measure against current coverage or an absolute threshold?
- Should the initial threshold be set based on current coverage or a target?

Let me ask about what happens when coverage drops, since that's a key user experience question.
response.generatedTitle: Clarified user preferences for PR interface.

response.value:
Thank you for that clarification! That helps me understand the visibility and enforcement preferences.

**Next Question:**

When code coverage drops below the threshold (or decreases from the baseline), what should the user experience be?

- **Scenario A:** PR check fails completely, blocking merge until coverage is restored
- **Scenario B:** PR check fails, but can be overridden by maintainers (with a reason)
- **Scenario C:** PR shows a warning/comment about coverage drop, but doesn't block merge
- **Scenario D:** Different behavior based on severity (e.g., minor drop = warning, major drop = block)

Which approach aligns best with your workflow preferences?

edits.text: # Feature: Code Coverage Reporting and Enforcement in CI

Add automated code coverage collection, reporting, and enforcement to the CI pipeline. This feature will track test coverage metrics over time, make them visible during PR review, and prevent coverage regressions while maintaining maintainer discretion.
- **Prevent coverage regressions:** Automatically detect when new code lacks adequate test coverage
- **Visibility during review:** See coverage metrics directly in the PR interface without switching contexts
- **Track trends:** Monitor coverage evolution over time to identify areas needing attention
- **Enforce quality standards:** Maintain minimum coverage thresholds while allowing justified exceptions
- **Discoverability:** Make coverage status immediately visible to new contributors via README badge
- Automated coverage collection on every PR and main branch build
- Line coverage and branch coverage tracking
- Coverage threshold enforcement as a required PR check
- Coverage metrics visible in PR interface (summary + optional detailed report link)
- Maintainer override capability for failed coverage checks
- Initial threshold determination based on current measured coverage
- Coverage applied to all production code in `src/` without exclusions
- Retrospective coverage analysis for past commits
- Per-file or per-module coverage targets (only repository-wide thresholds)
- Coverage collection for local development (CI only)
- Custom coverage exclusion rules or filters
1. **Submit PR** â†’ Coverage automatically collected during CI build
2. **View PR checks** â†’ See coverage status as a required check with pass/fail status
3. **Access metrics** â†’ Coverage summary visible in PR interface (e.g., comment or check details)
- PR check fails with clear indication of threshold violation
- Author can see which threshold(s) failed (line vs branch)
- Detailed report available via link for investigation
- Author adds tests to restore coverage or explains why override is justified
1. **Review PR** â†’ Coverage status immediately visible alongside other checks
- Review coverage drop details and author justification
- Override check if legitimate reason exists (e.g., untestable platform code)
3. **Monitor trends** â†’ Access historical coverage data via external dashboard
1. **View README** â†’ See current coverage badge showing overall project health
2. **Click badge** â†’ Access detailed coverage report for full codebase
- [ ] Coverage metrics collected on every PR without manual intervention
- [ ] Both line and branch coverage thresholds enforced as required PR checks
- [ ] Coverage summary visible in PR interface (not requiring external navigation for basic info)
- [ ] Detailed coverage reports accessible via one-click link from PR
- [ ] Failed coverage checks block PR merge (but can be overridden by maintainers)
- [ ] Coverage badge displayed in README showing current main branch coverage
- [ ] Historical coverage data preserved and accessible for trend analysis
- [ ] Initial thresholds set based on measured current coverage (not arbitrary values)
- [ ] Coverage applies uniformly to all production code in `src/` directory
- [ ] Coverage collection adds less than 2 minutes to CI pipeline duration
None at this time. All requirements have been clarified with the maintainer.

toolCalls.arguments:
{"filePath": "/home/mathias/git/tfplan2md/docs/features/043-code-coverage-ci/specification.md", "content": "# Feature: Code Coverage Reporting and Enforcement in CI

## Overview

Add automated code coverage collection, reporting, and enforcement to the CI pipeline. This feature will track test coverage metrics over time, make them visible during PR review, and prevent coverage regressions while maintaining maintainer discretion.

**Related Issue:** #326  
**Priority:** Major  
**Source:** Multi-model analysis findings (M-1)

## User Goals

- **Prevent coverage regressions:** Automatically detect when new code lacks adequate test coverage
- **Visibility during review:** See coverage metrics directly in the PR interface without switching contexts
- **Track trends:** Monitor coverage evolution over time to identify areas needing attention
- **Enforce quality standards:** Maintain minimum coverage thresholds while allowing justified exceptions
- **Discoverability:** Make coverage status immediately visible to new contributors via README badge

## Scope

### In Scope

- Automated coverage collection on every PR and main branch build
- Line coverage and branch coverage tracking
- Coverage threshold enforcement as a required PR check
- Coverage metrics visible in PR interface (summary + optional detailed report link)
- Coverage badge in README
- Historical coverage trend tracking
- Maintainer override capability for failed coverage checks
- Initial threshold determination based on current measured coverage
- Coverage applied to all production code in `src/` without exclusions

### Out of Scope

- Retrospective coverage analysis for past commits
- Per-file or per-module coverage targets (only repository-wide thresholds)
- Coverage collection for local development (CI only)
- Integration with IDE coverage tools
- Custom coverage exclusion rules or filters

## User Experience

### For PR Authors

1. **Submit PR** â†’ Coverage automatically collected during CI build
2. **View PR checks** â†’ See coverage status as a required check with pass/fail status
3. **Access metrics** â†’ Coverage summary visible in PR interface (e.g., comment or check details)
4. **If coverage drops:**
   - PR check fails with clear indication of threshold violation
   - Author can see which threshold(s) failed (line vs branch)
   - Detailed report available via link for investigation
   - Author adds tests to restore coverage or explains why override is justified

### For Maintainers

1. **Review PR** â†’ Coverage status immediately visible alongside other checks
2. **If check fails:**
   - Review coverage drop details and author justification
   - Override check if legitimate reason exists (e.g., untestable platform code)
   - Merge proceeds with documented override

3. **Monitor trends** â†’ Access historical coverage data via external dashboard

### For Contributors

1. **View README** â†’ See current coverage badge showing overall project health
2. **Click badge** â†’ Access detailed coverage report for full codebase

## Success Criteria

Coverage system is successful when:

- [ ] Coverage metrics collected on every PR without manual intervention
- [ ] Both line and branch coverage thresholds enforced as required PR checks
- [ ] Coverage summary visible in PR interface (not requiring external navigation for basic info)
- [ ] Detailed coverage reports accessible via one-click link from PR
- [ ] Failed coverage checks block PR merge (but can be overridden by maintainers)
- [ ] Coverage badge displayed in README showing current main branch coverage
- [ ] Historical coverage data preserved and accessible for trend analysis
- [ ] Initial thresholds set based on measured current coverage (not arbitrary values)
- [ ] Coverage applies uniformly to all production code in `src/` directory
- [ ] Coverage collection adds less than 2 minutes to CI pipeline duration

## Open Questions

None at this time. All requirements have been clarified with the maintainer.

## References

- GitHub Issue #326: https://github.com/oocx/tfplan2md/issues/326
- Multi-model review findings: `docs/workflow/multi-model-review/merged-findings.md` (M-1)
"}
